text: Determine accuracy one diagnostic test Compare accuracy two diagnostic tests Compute accuracy measures Compare predictive values Test based weighted generalized score statistic: Estimation test relative predictive values:
code: library(DTComPair) # Loading required package: PropCIs data(Paired1) # Hypothetical study data a1 <- tab.1test(d=d, y=y1, data=Paired1) print(a1) # Binary diagnostic test 'y1' #  #           Diseased Non-diseased Total # Test pos.      397           84   481 # Test neg.       54          177   231 # Total          451          261   712 a1 |> acc.1test(method.ci = "waldci") # default Wald intervals # Diagnostic accuracy of test 'y1' #  # (Estimates, standard errors and 95%-confidence intervals) #  #                  Est.         SE  Lower CL  Upper CL # Sensitivity 0.8802661 0.01528718 0.8503038 0.9102284 # Specificity 0.6781609 0.02891782 0.6214830 0.7348388 # PPV         0.8253638 0.01731081 0.7914353 0.8592924 # NPV         0.7662338 0.02784617 0.7116563 0.8208113 #  #            Est.  SE (log)  Lower CL  Upper CL # PDLR  2.7351124 0.0915147 2.2860079 3.2724472 # NDLR  0.1765568 0.1346088 0.1356142 0.2298601 a1 |> acc.1test(method.ci = "exactci") # Clopper-Pearson intervals # Diagnostic accuracy of test 'y1' #  # (Estimates, standard errors and 95%-confidence intervals) #  #                  Est. SE  Lower CL  Upper CL # Sensitivity 0.8802661 NA 0.8466745 0.9087592 # Specificity 0.6781609 NA 0.6177792 0.7344406 # PPV         0.8253638 NA 0.7884240 0.8582440 # NPV         0.7662338 NA 0.7062587 0.8192389 #  #            Est.  SE (log)  Lower CL  Upper CL # PDLR  2.7351124 0.0915147 2.2860079 3.2724472 # NDLR  0.1765568 0.1346088 0.1356142 0.2298601 b1 <- tab.paired(d = d, y1 = y1, y2 = y2, data = Paired1) print(b1) # Two binary diagnostic tests (paired design) #  # Test1: 'y1' # Test2: 'y2' #  # Diseased: #            Test1 pos. Test1 neg. Total # Test2 pos.        319         22   341 # Test2 neg.         78         32   110 # Total             397         54   451 #  # Non-diseased: #            Test1 pos. Test1 neg. Total # Test2 pos.         31         22    53 # Test2 neg.         53        155   208 # Total              84        177   261 b1 |> acc.paired(method.ci = "scoreci") # Wilson intervals # Diagnostic accuracy of test 'y1' #  # (Estimates, standard errors and 95%-confidence intervals) #  #                  Est. SE Lower CL Upper CL # Sensitivity 0.8802661 NA   0.8470   0.9071 # Specificity 0.6781609 NA   0.6193   0.7319 # PPV         0.8253638 NA   0.7889   0.8567 # NPV         0.7662338 NA   0.7076   0.8162 #  #            Est. SE Lower CL Upper CL # Sensitivity 0.7560976 NA   0.7144   0.7935 # Specificity 0.7969349 NA   0.7440   0.8413 # PPV         0.8654822 NA   0.8282   0.8957 # NPV         0.6540881 NA   0.6002   0.7042 #  #            Est.  SE (log)  Lower CL  Upper CL # PDLR  3.7234238 0.1255060 2.9114648 4.7618247 # NDLR  0.3060507 0.0885996 0.2572629 0.3640906 pv.wgs(b1)   # $ppv #          test1          test2           diff test.statistic        p.value  #     0.82536383     0.86548223     0.04011841     5.46588745     0.01939120  #  # $npv #          test1          test2           diff test.statistic        p.value  #   7.662338e-01   6.540881e-01  -1.121457e-01   1.653540e+01   4.775012e-05  #  # $method # [1] "weighted generalized score statistic (wgs)" pv.rpv(b1) # $ppv #          test1          test2           rppv    se.log.rppv       lcl.rppv  #     0.82536383     0.86548223     1.04860694     0.01991247     1.00847050  #       ucl.rppv test.statistic        p.value  #     1.09034078     2.38355929     0.01714612  #  # $npv #          test1          test2           rnpv    se.log.rnpv       lcl.rnpv  #   7.662338e-01   6.540881e-01   8.536403e-01   3.783679e-02   7.926258e-01  #       ucl.rnpv test.statistic        p.value  #   9.193516e-01  -4.182314e+00   2.885568e-05  #  # $Sigma #              log.rppv     log.rnpv # log.rppv 0.0003965065 0.0004024578 # log.rnpv 0.0004024578 0.0014316223 #  # $method # [1] "relative predictive values (rpv)" #  # $alpha # [1] 0.05

what: Estimating the Capacity for Improvement in Diagnostic Risk Prediction with an additional marker based on the Diagnostic Likelihood Ratio (DLR) — DLR
title: Estimating the Capacity for Improvement in Diagnostic Risk Prediction with an additional marker based on the Diagnostic Likelihood Ratio (DLR) — DLR
text: function allows estimating log diagnostic likelihood ratio regression model approach. can used assess gain diagnostic accuracy new binary continuous diagnostic marker compared established markers, determine impact covariates risk prediction model, estimate DLR selected marker/covariate values.

title: Estimating the Capacity for Improvement in Diagnostic Risk Prediction with an additional marker based on the Diagnostic Likelihood Ratio (DLR) — DLR
code: DLR(basemodel, augmentedmodel, diseasestatus, dataset, clustervar = NULL, alpha=0.05)

title: Estimating the Capacity for Improvement in Diagnostic Risk Prediction with an additional marker based on the Diagnostic Likelihood Ratio (DLR) — DLR
text: basemodel pre-test/base model X, formula character string augmentedmodel post-test/ augmented model V, formula character string,   usually basemodel X including additional diagnostic test interest Y interactions XY diseasestatus variable name containing disease status, assumed 0/1 variable, condition interest (1) (0), character string dataset dataframe, needs wide format one observation per subject clustervar optional, cluster variable name dataset, character string alpha significance level alpha used confidence intervals, default 0.05.

title: Estimating the Capacity for Improvement in Diagnostic Risk Prediction with an additional marker based on the Diagnostic Likelihood Ratio (DLR) — DLR
text: function implementation algorithm described appendix Gu Pepe (2009) using GEE approach order get standard error estimates. definition Zero matrices slightly flexible ones described section 3 order allow models without interaction.

title: Estimating the Capacity for Improvement in Diagnostic Risk Prediction with an additional marker based on the Diagnostic Likelihood Ratio (DLR) — DLR
text: Returns list including logPreTestModel logistic regression model output prior disease using base model X: P(D=1|X). estimates log scale. logPostTestModel logistic regression model output posterior disease using augmented model V: P(D=1|X,Y),.e. P(D=1|V). estimates log scale. logDLRModel regression model output log DLR defined difference logPostTestModel logPreTestModel. estimates log scale. DLR Positive/negative DLR diagnostic marker Y, base covariates X set 1. Results sensible binary marker Y taking values 0/1.

title: Estimating the Capacity for Improvement in Diagnostic Risk Prediction with an additional marker based on the Diagnostic Likelihood Ratio (DLR) — DLR
text: Gu, W. Pepe, M. S. (2009). Estimating capacity improvement risk prediction marker. Biostatistics, 10(1):172-86.

what: Accuracy of a Single Binary Diagnostic Test — acc.1test
title: Accuracy of a Single Binary Diagnostic Test — acc.1test
text: Sensitivity specificity, (positive negative) predictive values   (positive negative) diagnostic likelihood ratios single binary   diagnostic test.

title: Accuracy of a Single Binary Diagnostic Test — acc.1test
code: acc.1test(tab, alpha, testname, method.ci, ...)

title: Accuracy of a Single Binary Diagnostic Test — acc.1test
text: tab object class tab.1test. alpha Significance level alpha 100(1-alpha)%-confidence intervals,   default 0.05. testname character string containing name diagnostic test. method.ci character string name function compute   confidence intervals sensitivity, specificity, predictive values.   default ''waldci'' Wald asymptotic normal-based confidence   intervals. See 'Details'. ... Additional arguments (usually required).

title: Accuracy of a Single Binary Diagnostic Test — acc.1test
text: calculation accuracy measures follows standard methodology, e.g. described Pepe (2003) Zhou et al. (2011). confidence intervals sensitivity, specificity, predictive values computed using methodology implemented function passed argument method.ci. Available options : waldci - Wald asymptotic normal-based confidence interval;   default, logitci - asymptotic normal-based confidence interval   logit scale back-transformed, exactci - Clopper-Pearson exact confidence interval, add4cici - Agresti-Coull add-4 confidence interval, addz2ci - Agresti-Coull add-z^2/2 confidence interval, blakerci - Blaker exact confidence interval, scoreci - Wilson score confidence interval, midPci - mid-P confidence interval. Options (3) (8) based homonymous functions {PropCIs} package. Please see respective package documentation details. Confidence intervals diagnostic likelihood ratios computed according Simel et al. (1991).

title: Accuracy of a Single Binary Diagnostic Test — acc.1test
text: list class acc.1test: tab contingency table (matrix) test results; tab supplied argument. sensitivity numeric vector containing estimated sensitivity (est), standard error (se), lower confidence limit (lcl) upper confidence limit (ucl). specificity numeric vector containing estimated specificity (est), standard error (se), lower confidence limit (lcl) upper confidence limit (ucl). ppv numeric vector containing estimated positive predictive value (est), standard error (se), lower confidence limit (lcl) upper confidence limit (ucl). npv numeric vector containing estimated negative predictive value (est), standard error (se), lower confidence limit (lcl) upper confidence limit (ucl). pdlr numeric vector containing estimated positive diagnostic likelihood ratio (est), standard error logarithm positive diagnostic likelihood ratio (se.ln), lower confidence limit (lcl) upper confidence limit (ucl). ndlr numeric vector containing estimated negative diagnostic likelihood ratio (est), standard error logarithm negative diagnostic likelihood ratio (se.ln), lower confidence limit (lcl) upper confidence limit (ucl). alpha significance level alpha used compute 100(1-alpha)%-confidence intervals, default 0.05. testname character string containing name diagnostic test. method.ci character string describing method used compute confidence intervals sensitivity, specificity, predictive values.

title: Accuracy of a Single Binary Diagnostic Test — acc.1test
text: Pepe, M. (2003). statistical evaluation medical tests classification prediction. Oxford Statistical Science Series. Oxford University Press, 1st edition. Simel, D.L., Samsa, G.P., Matchar, D.B. (1991). Likelihood ratios confidence: sample size estimation diagnostic test studies. J Clin Epidemiol, 44(8):763-70. Zhou, X., Obuchowski, N., McClish, D. (2011). Statistical Methods Diagnostic Medicine. Wiley Series Probability Statistics. John Wiley & Sons, Hoboken, New Jersey, 2nd edition.

title: Accuracy of a Single Binary Diagnostic Test — acc.1test
code: data(Paired1) # Hypothetical study data  a1 <- tab.1test(d=d, y=y1, data=Paired1) a2 <- acc.1test(a1) print(a2) #> Diagnostic accuracy of test 'y1' #>  #> (Estimates, standard errors and 95%-confidence intervals) #>  #>                  Est.         SE  Lower CL  Upper CL #> Sensitivity 0.8802661 0.01528718 0.8503038 0.9102284 #> Specificity 0.6781609 0.02891782 0.6214830 0.7348388 #> PPV         0.8253638 0.01731081 0.7914353 0.8592924 #> NPV         0.7662338 0.02784617 0.7116563 0.8208113 #>  #>            Est.  SE (log)  Lower CL  Upper CL #> PDLR  2.7351124 0.0915147 2.2860079 3.2724472 #> NDLR  0.1765568 0.1346088 0.1356142 0.2298601 a3 <- acc.1test(a1, method="exactci", conf.level=0.99) print(a3) #> Diagnostic accuracy of test 'y1' #>  #> (Estimates, standard errors and 95%-confidence intervals) #>  #>                  Est. SE  Lower CL  Upper CL #> Sensitivity 0.8802661 NA 0.8466745 0.9087592 #> Specificity 0.6781609 NA 0.6177792 0.7344406 #> PPV         0.8253638 NA 0.7884240 0.8582440 #> NPV         0.7662338 NA 0.7062587 0.8192389 #>  #>            Est. what: Differences in Diagnostic Likelihood Ratios — dlr.regtest
title: Differences in Diagnostic Likelihood Ratios — dlr.regtest
text: Performs test differences (positive negative) diagnostic likelihood ratios (DLRs) two binary diagnostic tests paired study using regression model approach proposed Gu Pepe (2009).

title: Differences in Diagnostic Likelihood Ratios — dlr.regtest
code: dlr.regtest(tab, alpha)

title: Differences in Diagnostic Likelihood Ratios — dlr.regtest
text: tab object class tab.paired. alpha Significance level alpha 100(1-alpha)%-confidence intervals, default 0.05.

title: Differences in Diagnostic Likelihood Ratios — dlr.regtest
text: null hypothesis rDLR = DLR Test 1 / DLR Test 2 = 1 tested respect positive negative DLRs two diagnostic tests. function calls DLR, general implementation method proposed Gu Pepe (2009).

title: Differences in Diagnostic Likelihood Ratios — dlr.regtest
text: list containing pdlr list     test1 (positive DLR test 1),     test2 (positive DLR test 2),     ratio (ratio positive DLRs, computed test1/test2,     se.log (standard error logarithm ratio),     test.statistic corresponding p.value. ndlr list     test1 (negative DLR test 1),     test2 (negative DLR test 2),     ratio (ratio negative DLRs, computed test1/test2,     se.log (standard error logarithm ratio),     test.statistic corresponding p.value. alpha significance level alpha used compute 100(1-alpha)%-confidence intervals ratio positive negative DLRs, default 0.05. method name method used compare positive negative DLRs, “diagnostic likelihood regression model (regtest)”.

title: Differences in Diagnostic Likelihood Ratios — dlr.regtest
text: Gu, W. Pepe, M. S. (2009). Estimating capacity improvement risk prediction marker. Biostatistics, 10(1):172-86.

title: Differences in Diagnostic Likelihood Ratios — dlr.regtest
code: data(Paired1) # Hypothetical study data ptab <- tab.paired(d=d, y1=y1, y2=y2, data=Paired1) ptab #> Two binary diagnostic tests (paired design) #>  #> Test1: 'y1' #> Test2: 'y2' #>  #> Diseased: #>            Test1 pos. Test1 neg. Total #> Test2 pos.        319         22   341 #> Test2 neg.         78         32   110 #> Total             397         54   451 #>  #> Non-diseased: #>            Test1 pos. Test1 neg. Total #> Test2 pos.         31         22    53 #> Test2 neg.         53        155   208 #> Total              84        177   261 #>  dlr.results <- dlr.regtest(ptab) str(dlr.results) #> List of 4 #>  $ pdlr  :List of 8 #>   ..$ test1         : num 2.74 #>   ..$ test2         : num 3.72 #>   ..$ ratio         : num 0.735 #>   ..$ se.log        : num 0.133 #>   ..$ test.statistic: num -2.33 #>   ..$ p.value       : num 0.02 #>   ..$ lcl           : num 0.566 #>   ..$ ucl           : num 0.953 #>  $ ndlr  :List of 8 #>   ..$ test1         : num 0.177 #>   ..$ test2         : num 0.306 #>   ..$ ratio         : num 0.577 #>   ..$ se.log        : num 0.137 #>   ..$ test.statistic: num -4 #>   ..$ p.value       : num 6.22e-05 #>   ..$ lcl           : num 0.441 #>   ..$ ucl           : num 0.755 #>  $ alpha : num 0.05 #>  $ method: chr "DLR regression model (regtest)" dlr.results #> $pdlr #> $pdlr$test1 #> [1] 2.735112 #>  #> $pdlr$test2 #> [1] 3.723424 #>  #> $pdlr$ratio #> [1] 0.7345692 #>  #> $pdlr$se.log #> [1] 0.1326086 #>  #> $pdlr$test.statistic #> [1] -2.326177 #>  #> $pdlr$p.value #> [1] 0.0200091 #>  #> $pdlr$lcl #> [1] 0.5664428 #>  #> $pdlr$ucl #> [1] 0.9525973 #>  #>  #> $ndlr #> $ndlr$test1 #> [1] 0.1765568 #>  #> $ndlr$test2 #> [1] 0.3060507 #>  #> $ndlr$ratio #> [1] 0.5768875 #>  #> $ndlr$se.log #> [1] 0.137376 #>  #> $ndlr$test.statistic #> [1] -4.004396 #>  #> $ndlr$p.value #> [1] 6.217627e-05 #>  #> $ndlr$lcl #> [1] 0.4407136 #>  #> $ndlr$ucl #> [1] 0.7551371 #>  #>  #> $alpha #> [1] 0.05 #>  #> $method #> [1] "DLR regression model (regtest)" #>

title: Elliptical joint confidence region for relative positive and negative predictive value — ellipse.pv.rpv
text: x object returned pv.rpv function. alpha significance level alpha used compute 100(1-alpha)% region. default 0.05, 95% region. npoints number points used ellipse. Default 100. exponentiate logical value indicating whether exponentiate values centre ellipse ellipsoidal outline. Defaults FALSE.

text: Moskowitz, C.S., Pepe, M.S. (2006). Comparing predictive values diagnostic tests: sample size analysis paired study designs. Clin Trials, 3(3):272-9.

title: Elliptical joint confidence region for relative positive and negative predictive value — ellipse.pv.rpv
code: data(Paired1) # Hypothetical study data ftable(Paired1) #>      y2   0   1 #> d y1            #> 0 0     155  22 #>   1      53  31 #> 1 0      32  22 #>   1      78 319 paired.layout <- tab.paired(d=d, y1=y1, y2=y2, data=Paired1) paired.layout  #> Two binary diagnostic tests (paired design) #>  #> Test1: 'y1' #> Test2: 'y2' #>  #> Diseased: #>            Test1 pos. Test1 neg. Total #> Test2 pos.        319         22   341 #> Test2 neg.         78         32   110 #> Total             397         54   451 #>  #> Non-diseased: #>            Test1 pos. Test1 neg. Total #> Test2 pos.         31         22    53 #> Test2 neg.         53        155   208 #> Total              84        177   261 #>  rpv.results <- pv.rpv(paired.layout) ellipse.data <- ellipse.pv.rpv(rpv.results) if(interactive()){   plot(ellipse.data$ellipse, type = "l", ylim = c(-0.4, 0.2), xlim = c(-0.2, 0.2))   points(ellipse.data$centre[1], ellipse.data$centre[2], col = "red", pch = 19)   abline(h = 0, v = 0, lty = 3) }

what: Compute predictive values for theoretical prevalences — pv.prev
title: Compute predictive values for theoretical prevalences — pv.prev
text: often interest estimate predictive values assuming test applied population different prevalence disease. Projected predictive values may calculated using Bayes theorem relation predictive values diagnostic likelihood ratios can used derived corresponding confidence intervals.

title: Compute predictive values for theoretical prevalences — pv.prev
code: pv.prev(pi, acc)

title: Compute predictive values for theoretical prevalences — pv.prev
text: pi theoretical prevalence disease (proportion). acc object class `acc.1test`.

title: Compute predictive values for theoretical prevalences — pv.prev
text: vector containing projected values.

title: Compute predictive values for theoretical prevalences — pv.prev
text: Predictive values, assuming certain prevalence disease, derived using relation predictive values diagnostic likelihood ratios: - PPV = 1 / (1 + (1 / pi - 1) / pDLR)   - NPV = 1 / (1 + (1 / (1 / pi - 1)) / nDLR). See Newcombe RG (2013). Confidence Intervals Proportions Related Measures Effect Size. Chapman Hall/ CRC Biostatistics Series (chapters 12.3+5 14.9). alpha-level (1-alpha)-confidence intervals inherited `acc.1test`.

title: Compute predictive values for theoretical prevalences — pv.prev
code: data(Paired1) # Hypothetical study data  a1 <- tab.1test(d=d, y=y1, data=Paired1) a2 <- acc.1test(a1, alpha = 0.05) pv.prev(pi=0.2, acc=a2) #>        pi   ppv_est   ppv_lcl   ppv_ucl   npv_est   npv_lcl   npv_ucl  #> 0.2000000 0.4060975 0.3636661 0.4499788 0.4139116 0.3516837 0.4790149  pv.prev(pi=0.5, acc=a2) #>        pi   ppv_est   ppv_lcl   ppv_ucl   npv_est   npv_lcl   npv_ucl  #> 0.5000000 0.7322704 0.6956794 0.7659421 0.1500623 0.1194193 0.1868994

title: Comparison of Predictive Values using Relative Predictive Values — pv.rpv
text: list containing: ppv named vector containing test1 (positive predictive value test 1), test2 (positive predictive value test 2), rppv (relative positive predictive value, computed test2 / test1), se.log.rppv (standard error logarithm rppv), lcl.rppv (lower confidence limit rppv), ucl.rppv (upper confidence limit rppv), test.statistic corresponding p.value. npv named vector containing test1 (negative predictive value test 1), test2 (negative predictive value test 2), rnpv (relative negative predictive value, computed test2 / test1), se.log.rnpv (standard error logarithm rnpv), lcl.rnpv (lower confidence limit rnpv), ucl.rnpv (upper confidence limit rnpv), test.statistic corresponding p.value. Sigma Estimated variance-covariance matrix {log(relative positive predictive value), log(relative negative predictive value)}. method Name method used compare predictive values, “relative predictive values (rpv)”. alpha Significance level alpha used compute 100(1-alpha)%-confidence intervals rppv rnpv, default 0.05.

title: Comparison of Predictive Values using Relative Predictive Values — pv.rpv
text: Moskowitz, C.S., Pepe, M.S. (2006). Comparing predictive values diagnostic tests: sample size analysis paired study designs. Clin Trials, 3(3):272-9.

title: Confidence Intervals for Differences in Sensitivity and Specificity — sesp.diff.ci
code: sesp.diff.ci(tab, ci.method, alpha, cont.corr)

title: Confidence Intervals for Differences in Sensitivity and Specificity — sesp.diff.ci
text: tab object class tab.paired. ci.method available methods “wald” (Altman, 1991), “agresti-min” (Agresti Min, 2005), “bonett-price” (Bonett Price, 2011), “tango” (Tango, 1998), default “wald”. alpha Significance level alpha 100(1-alpha)%-confidence intervals difference sensitivity specificity, default 0.05. cont.corr logical value indicating whether continuity correction used (available ci.method="wald"), default FALSE.

title: Confidence Intervals for Differences in Sensitivity and Specificity — sesp.diff.ci
text: details recommendations see Newcombe (2012) Wenzel Zapf (2013).

title: Confidence Intervals for Differences in Sensitivity and Specificity — sesp.diff.ci
text: list containing: sensitivity vector containing    test1 (sensitivity test 1),    test2 (specificity test 2),    diff (difference two sensitivities, computed test2 - test1),    diff.se (standard error diff),    diff.lcl (lower confidence limit diff)    diff.ucl (upper confidence limit diff). specificity vector containing    test1 (specificity test 1),    test2 (specificity test 2),    diff (difference two specificities, computed test2 - test1),    diff.se (standard error diff),    diff.lcl (lower confidence limit diff)    diff.ucl (upper confidence limit diff). ci.method name method used calculate confidence intervals. alpha level alpha used compute 100(1-alpha)%-confidence intervals. cont.corr logical value indicating whether continuity correction applied.

title: Confidence Intervals for Differences in Sensitivity and Specificity — sesp.diff.ci
text: Altman, D.G. (1991). Practical statistics medical research. Chapman & Hall, London. Agresti, . Min, Y. (2005). Simple improved confidence intervals comparing matched proportions. Stat Med, 24(5): 729-40. Bonett, D.G., Price, R.M. (2011). Adjusted Wald confidence intervals difference binomial proportions based paired data. J Educ Behav Stat, 37(4): 479-488.  Newcombe R.G. (2012). Confidence intervals proportions related measures effect size. Chapman Hall/CRC Biostatistics Series. Tango, T. (1998). Equivalence test confidence interval difference proportions paired-sample design. Stat Med, 17(8): 891-908. Wenzel, D., Zapf, . (2013). Difference two dependent sensitivities specificities: comparison various approaches. Biom J, 55(5): 705-718.

title: DTComPair version 1.2.6 (2024-09-24)
text: CRAN release: 2024-09-24 functions acc.1test() acc.paired() now allow user (via argument method.ci)choose range differnt types confidence intervals.

title: DTComPair version 1.2.4 (2024-04-10)
text: CRAN release: 2024-04-10 functions tab.paired() tab.1test() now allow data subjects either diseased nondiseased. link package website hex sticker added.

title: DTComPair version 1.2.2 (2023-08-20)
text: CRAN release: 2023-08-20 Functions compare sensitivity/ specificity predictive values now return lists vectors (instead lists lists). Test 1 consistently used reference test. pv.gs()pv.wgs(), now diff.ppv <- ppv.2-ppv.1 (instead diff.ppv <- abs(ppv.1-ppv.2)), accordingly negative predictive values. Added new function (pv.prev()) allow computation positive negative predictive values different theoretical prevalences. Added new function (sesp.gen.mcnemar()) implementing generalized McNemar’s test joint comparison sensitivity specificity. redundant table man/dtcompair-package.rd deleted.

title: DTComPair version 1.2.0 (2023-04-20)
text: CRAN release: 2023-04-21 pv.rpv() now returns full variance-covariance matrix (Sigma). ellipse.pv.rpv() generates data plot joint confidence region rPPV rNPV (depends ellipse package) (Moskowitz Pepe, 2006). sesp.rel() calculates relative sensitivity relative specificity (Wald CIs p-value). tpffpf.rel() calculates relative sensitivity (rTPF) relative ‘one minus specificity’ (rFPF) (Wald CIs p-value), calculate individual components (ie, TPFs FPFs); function meant used paired screen-positive designs, rTPF rFPF estimable form data (see Cheng Macaluso, 1997 Alonzo, Pepe, Moskowitz, 2002). new features contributed . Discacciati - many thanks!

title: DTComPair version 1.1.0 (2023-02-21)
text: CRAN release: 2023-02-23 Restored compatibility CRAN requirements.

title: DTComPair version 1.0.3 (2014-02-14)
text: CRAN release: 2014-02-16 Corrected error sesp.diff.ci (detected F. Gimenez - many thanks!). Minor documentation update.

title: DTComPair version 1.0.2 (2013-11-12)
text: CRAN release: 2013-11-15 Corrected error function sesp.exactbinom (detected J. Swiecicki - many thanks!). Minor documentation update.
